qas.question: What is another name for an elevator shaft?
Elevator drive mechanisms have, in the past been, powered by what?

answers.text: steam and water hydraulic pistons or by hand

qas.question: What is the weight of the elevator cage balanced by?
How do elevators built in pairs work?

answers.text: their cars always move synchronously in opposite directions,

context: Some people argue that elevators began as simple rope or chain hoists (see Traction elevators below). An elevator is essentially a platform that is either pulled or pushed up by a mechanical means. A modern-day elevator consists of a cab (also called a "cage", "carriage" or "car") mounted on a platform within an enclosed space called a shaft or sometimes a "<a0_0>hoistway<a0_0/>". In the past, elevator drive mechanisms were powered by <a1_0>steam and water hydraulic pistons or by hand<a1_0/>. In a "traction" elevator, cars are pulled up by means of rolling steel ropes over a deeply grooved pulley, commonly called a sheave in the industry. The weight of the car is balanced by <a2_0>a counterweight<a2_0/>. Sometimes two elevators are built so that <a3_0>their cars always move synchronously in opposite directions,<a3_0/> and are each other's counterweight.
